title-group.article-title: The Convergence of the Ben-Israel Iteration for Nonlinear Least Squares Problems

abstract.p: Ben-Israel [1] proposed a method for the solution of the nonlinear least squares problem $\min_{x \in D}\|F(x)\|_2$ where $F: D \subset R^n \rightarrow R^m$. This procedure takes the form $x_{k+1} = x_k - F'(x_k)^+F(x_k)$ where $F'(x_k)^+$ denotes the Moore-Penrose generalized inverse of the Fréchet derivative of $F$. We give a general convergence theorem for the method based on Lyapunov stability theory for ordinary difference equations. In the case where there is a connected set of solution points, it is often of interest to determine the minimum norm least squares solution. We show that the Ben-Israel iteration has no predisposition toward the minimum norm solution, but that any limit point of the sequence generated by the Ben-Israel iteration is a least squares solution.
